column3:
G. Fabricius (1 and 2), E. Artacho (1 and 3), D. Sanchez-Portal (1),
  P. Ordejon (4), D. A. Drabold (5) and J. M. Soler (1) ((1) Madrid, Spain, (2)
  La Plata, Argentina, (3) Lyon, France, (4) Oviedo, Spain, (5) Athens, USA)
column4:
Atomic layering at the liquid silicon surface: a first- principles
  simulation
column11:
We simulate the liquid silicon surface with first-principles molecular
dynamics in a slab geometry. We find that the atom-density profile presents a
pronounced layering, similar to those observed in low-temperature liquid metals
like Ga and Hg. The depth-dependent pair correlation function shows that the
effect originates from directional bonding of Si atoms at the surface, and
propagates into the bulk. The layering has no major effects in the electronic
and dynamical properties of the system, that are very similar to those of bulk
liquid Si. To our knowledge, this is the first study of a liquid surface by
first-principles molecular dynamics.

column5:
4 pages, Latex2e, revtex, no figures, introduction of equations and
  relation to experiments become clearer
column11:
Icicles with wave patterns on their surfaces can sometimes be seen hanging
from roofs of buildings. Surprisingly, most of these wave patterns are at
intervals of about 1 cm. The reason for this uniformity of interval has not
been clarified. Here we show a formula to explain this remarkable phenomenon by
introducing a new instability theory. This theory is given by thermal diffusion
in thin water layer streams flowing along the icicles. The streams change the
temperature distribution and control waves of short wavelengths. The specific
wavelength (about 1 cm) can be determined by Laplace instability of the heat
field in the atmosphere and by the thermal diffusion effect in thin-layer
streams.
column12: [{"version":"v1","created":"Sun, 25 Jul 1999 03:38:18 GMT"},{"version":"v2","created":"Wed, 17 Oct 2001 05:29:34 GMT"},{"version":"v3","created":"Mon, 3 Dec 2001 11:26:01 GMT"},{"version":"v4","created":"Tue, 4 Dec 2001 11:19:22 GMT"},{"version":"v5","created":"Wed, 5 Dec 2001 01:47:12 GMT"},{"version":"v6","created":"Wed, 12 Dec 2001 07:40:28 GMT"},{"version":"v7","created":"Thu, 13 Dec 2001 04:45:12 GMT"}]

column3: Moshe Carmeli (Ben Gurion U.) and Shimon Malin (Colgate U.)
column4:
SL(2,C) Gauge Theory of Gravitation and the Quantization of the
  Gravitational Field
column5:
6 pages, published in Intern. j. Theor. Phys. Vol. 37, No. 10,
  pp.2615-2620 (1998)
column11:
A new approach to quantize the gravitational field is presented. It is based
on the observation that the quantum character of matter becomes more
significant as one gets closer to the big bang. As the metric loses its
meaning, it makes sense to consider Schrodinger's three generic types of
manifolds - unconnected differentiable, affinely connected, and metrically
connected - as a temporal sequence following the big bang. Hence one should
quantize the gravitational field on general differentiable manifolds or on
affinely connected manifolds. The SL(2,C) gauge theory of gravitation is
employed to explore this possibility. Within this framework, the quantization
itself may well be canonical.

column3: D. Neyret, T. Pussieux, et al
column4:
A photon calorimeter using lead tungstate crystals for the CEBAF Hall A
  Compton polarimeter
column11:
The performances of the calorimeter of the Jlab Hall A Compton Polarimeter
have been measured using the Mainz tagged photon beam.

column3: Hugo Garcia-Compean and Jerzy F. Plebanski
column4: D-branes on Group Manifolds and Deformation Quantization
column5: 20 pages, harvmac file, no figures, corrected typos
column11:
Recently M. Kontsevich found a combinatorial formula defining a star-product
of deformation quantization for any Poisson manifold. Kontsevich's formula has
been reinterpreted physically as quantum correlation functions of a topological
sigma model for open strings as well as in the context of D-branes in flat
backgrounds with a Neveu-Schwarz B-field. Here the corresponding Kontsevich's
formula for the dual of a Lie algebra is derived in terms of the formalism of
D-branes on group manifolds. In particular we show that that formula is encoded
at the two-point correlation functions of the Wess-Zumino-Witten effective
theory with Dirichlet boundary conditions. The B-field entering in the
formalism plays an important role in this derivation.

column3: I. Antoniadis, G. D'Appollonio, E. Dudas and A. Sagnotti
column4: Open Descendants of Z_2\times Z_2 Freely-Acting Orbifolds
column11:
We discuss Z_2 \times Z_2 orientifolds where the orbifold twists are
accompanied by shifts on momentum or winding lattice states. The models contain
variable numbers of D5 branes, whose massless (and, at times, even massive)
modes have variable numbers of supersymmetries. We display new type-I models
with partial supersymmetry breaking N=2 \to N=1, N=4 \to N=1 and N=4 \to N=2.
The geometry of these models is rather rich: the shift operations create brane
multiplets related by orbifold transformations that support gauge groups of
reduced rank. Some of the models are deformations of six-dimensional
supersymmetric type-I models, while others have dual M-theory descriptions.

column3:
Nicolai Reshetikhin, Milen Yakimov (University of California at
  Berkeley)
column4: Deformation Quantization of Lagrangian Fiber Bundles
column6:
Conference Moshe Flato 1999, vol. 2, 269-288, Kluwer Acad. Publ.
  2000
column11:
Let (M, \om) be a symplectic manifold. A Lagrangian fiber bundle \pi : M -> B
determines a completely integrable system on M. First integrals of this system
are the pull-backs of functions on the base of the bundle. We show that for
each Lagrangian fiber bundle \pi there exist star products on C^\infty(M)[[h]]
which do not deform the pointwise multiplication on the subalgebra
\pi^*(C^\infty (B)) [[h]]. The set of equivalence classes of such star products
is in bijection with formal deformations of the symplectic structure \om for
which \pi : M -> B remains Lagrangian taken modulo formal symplectomorphisms of
M.

column4: A Fredholm determinant formula for Toeplitz determinants
column11:
We prove a formula expressing a general n by n Toeplitz determinant as a
Fredholm determinant of an operator 1-K acting on l_2({n,n+1,...}), where the
kernel K admits an integral representation in terms of the symbol of the
original Toeplitz matrix.
  The proof is based on the results of one of the authors, see math.RT/9907127,
and a formula due to Gessel which expands any Toeplitz determinant into a
series of Schur functions.
  We also consider 3 examples where the kernel involves the Gauss
hypergeometric function and its degenerations.

column4: Flow and equation of state in heavy-ion collisions
column5: 11 pages, 12 figures, talk given at Quark Matter '99, Torino, Italy
column11:
The status of flow in heavy-ion collisions and of inference of
hadronic-matter properties is reviewed.

The event-by-event azimuthal fluctuations in high-energy heavy-ion collisions
are analyzed by means of the so-called Phi-measure. The fluctuations due to the
collective transverse flow and those caused by the quantum statistics and
resonance decays in the hadron gas are discussed in detail.
